questions.text: A 32-year-old 70 kg male posted for Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy is undergoing surgery under General Anaesthesia. Maintenance fluid used is Ringer’s Lactate (RL) 140 ml/hour started intra-operatively. Which of these is not a component of RL?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Magnesium - 3 mEq/litre

 

Option D: RL does not contain magnesium ions (Mg2+). Magnesium is another essential electrolyte in the body, involved in muscle and nerve function, as well as various enzymatic reactions.

 

Ringer’s Lactate or Hartmann Solution contains: -

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ringer's Lactate (RL) contains sodium ions (Na+) at a concentration of 130 mEq/litre. Sodium is an essential electrolyte involved in various physiological processes, including maintaining fluid balance and nerve function.

 

Option B. RL contains potassium ions (K+) at a concentration of 4 mEq/litre. Potassium is another crucial electrolyte that plays a role in muscle function, nerve transmission, and maintaining heart rhythm.

 

Option C. RL includes chloride ions (Cl-) at a concentration of 110 mEq/litre. Chloride is an important anion in the body and is often found in conjunction with sodium and potassium, helping to maintain electrical neutrality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ringer's Lactate (RL) is a balanced crystalloid solution used for fluid replacement during surgery and in various clinical settings. It contains sodium, potassium, and chloride ions but does not contain magnesium ions. Understanding the composition of RL is important for proper fluid management in medical practice.

 

 

Ref: Marino ICU book 4th edition

questions.text: Which crystalloid is most Iso-Osmolar to Plasma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ringer’s lactate

 

Option A: Ringer's Lactate:

 

  • Osmolarity: Ringer's lactate has an osmolarity of approximately 280 mOsm/litre.
  • Explanation: Ringer's lactate is an isotonic crystalloid solution that closely matches the osmolarity of normal plasma. It contains electrolytes like sodium, potassium, and calcium, making it a suitable choice for fluid replacement in various clinical settings.

 

The normal plasma osmolarity is in the range of 280-300 mOsm/kg. 

 

Ringer lactate – Osmolarity – 280 mOsm/litre

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Normal Saline (0.9% NaCl):

 

  • Osmolarity: Normal saline has an osmolarity of 308 mOsm/litre.
  • Explanation: While normal saline is commonly used as an intravenous fluid, it has a slightly higher osmolarity compared to plasma. It is considered isotonic but not perfectly iso-osmolar.

 

Option C. 5% Dextrose:

 

  • Osmolarity: 5% dextrose (in water) has an osmolarity of 278 mOsm/litre.
  • Explanation: 5% dextrose is a hypotonic solution with an osmolarity lower than that of plasma. It is often used as a maintenance fluid or as a source of calories, but it is not iso-osmolar to plasma.

 

Option D. DNS (Dextrose in Normal Saline):

 

  • Osmolarity: DNS typically has an osmolarity of 560 mOsm/litre, but it can vary based on the concentration of dextrose added.
  • Explanation: DNS is a hypertonic solution because of the added dextrose, which increases its osmolarity well above that of plasma. It is not iso-osmolar to plasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Marino ICU book 4th edition Pg 234

questions.text: A 30-year-old with traumatic brain injury is admitted to the ICU with cerebral oedema and raised intracranial pressure. The intensivist asks for 3% hypertonic saline to reduce the oedema and ICP. What is the Na+ concentration and osmolarity of 3% hypertonic saline?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Na+- 513 meq/litre and 1030 mOsm/litre

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: 3% saline means 3 grams of sodium chloride per 100 milliliters of water. Since the molecular weight of Sodium Chloride (NaCl) is approximately 58.5 grams per mole, 3 grams of NaCl is roughly 0.051 moles. There are 1000 milliliters in a liter, so 3% saline has 0.51 moles of NaCl per liter. Since NaCl dissociates into two particles (Na+ and Cl-), it will result in (0.51 moles x 2) 1.02 osmoles per liter.

 

To convert moles of Na+ to milliequivalents (meq), you multiply by the valence of sodium, which is 1, and then by 1000 (for milli-), giving us 510 meq/L. The osmolarity would then be double the moles of NaCl because it dissociates into two particles, resulting in approximately 1020 mOsm/L. This option is almost correct but rounds the osmolarity to 1030 mOsm/L.

 

Educational Objective:

 

0.9% Normal Saline – Na+- 154 meq/litre and 308 mOsm/litre

 

3% Hypertonic Saline - Na+- 513 meq/litre and 1030 mOsm/litre

 

5% Hypertonic Saline - Na+- 856 meq/litre and 1710 mOsm/litre

 

Ref: Marino ICU book 4th edition

choices.text: 0.9% normal saline is a better choice of crystalloid than 0.45% ns during this patient’s surgery.
Intra-operative fluid restriction is good as dehydration is good for the brain.
Goal directed fluid therapy may contribute to decreased postoperative complications.
Hydrochlorothiazide (hctz) administered the morning of surgery should not prevent surgery from proceeding.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of hypertension presents for craniotomy and right frontal tumour resection. After running her bike into a tree, she has a headache and no neurodeficits. A head CT was significant for a 5cm well-circumscribed tumour with surrounding cerebral oedema. No other injuries were noted. Her BP (130/70) is well-controlled on hydrochlorothiazide. All of the following are true regarding fluid management in this patient except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intra-operative fluid restriction is good as dehydration is good for the brain.

 

Option B: This is not true. The goal for neurosurgical patients is to achieve euvolemia. While overhydration can exacerbate cerebral edema, dehydration can lead to hypotension and decreased cerebral perfusion, especially in a patient on diuretics like hydrochlorothiazide. Adequate intravenous (IV) fluid administration is critical to avoid hypotension and maintain cerebral perfusion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This is true. Administration of a hypo-osmolar solution like 0.45% NS (154 mOsmol/L) when compared to plasma (295 mOsmol/L) will promote water movement into the brain, exacerbating cerebral edema. 0.9% normal saline, with an osmolarity of 308 mOsmol/L, is considered iso-osmolar to slightly hyperosmolar relative to plasma, thus helping to avoid an increase in brain water content and intracranial pressure (ICP).

 

Option C. This is true. Goal-directed fluid therapy uses dynamic parameters to guide fluid administration intraoperatively, improving outcomes in various surgical procedures by optimizing volume status without overloading the patient.

 

Option D. This is true. While hydrochlorothiazide can cause volume contraction and potentially hypotension, it does not contraindicate surgery if vital signs are stable and electrolytes, especially potassium, are within normal limits. Adequate IV access and availability of vasopressors can mitigate the risk of hypotension during anesthesia induction and maintenance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intraoperative fluid management for a neurosurgical patient should aim for euvolemia, using isotonic fluids like 0.9% normal saline to avoid exacerbation of cerebral edema, while avoiding dehydration which can lead to hypotension and decreased cerebral perfusion.

 

Ref: Tommasino, Fluids and the neurosurgical patient, Anesthesiology Clin of N. Am. 20 (2002), 329-346

 

Luo, et. al., Goal-directed fluid restriction during brain surgery: a prospective randomized controlled trial. Ann. Intensive Care (2017); 7:16:1-7

 

Stoelting R, Pharmacology and Physiology, 5th edition

questions.text: Changes in intravascular volume in neurosurgical patients can be caused by all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inhalational Anaesthetics

 

Option D: Inhalational Anesthetics, while they are vasodilators and can decrease cardiac filling pressures, do not directly cause a change in the intravascular volume. They affect the vascular resistance and cardiac function, but they do not remove or add fluid to the intravascular space.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hemorrhage can lead to a significant decrease in intravascular volume. In neurosurgical trauma patients with blood loss, hemorrhage can cause hemodynamic instability and decreased tissue perfusion, which may necessitate transfusions of blood products and fluids to maintain adequate circulation and oxygen delivery.

 

Option B. Mannitol, an osmotic diuretic, increases plasma osmolarity, pulling fluid from the intracellular to the extracellular space, including from the brain, which helps to decrease intracranial pressure (ICP). While this can temporarily increase intravascular volume, it could be harmful in patients with compromised myocardial function.

 

Option C. Diabetes insipidus (DI) can occur in neurosurgical patients with lesions affecting the hypothalamus or after pituitary surgery. It leads to the excretion of large volumes of dilute urine due to inadequate release of vasopressin, which can result in significant hypovolemia and hypotension if not treated appropriately with fluids and vasopressin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemorrhage, osmotic diuretics, and diabetes insipidus can all cause changes in intravascular volume in neurosurgical patients, while inhalational anesthetics affect hemodynamics without directly altering intravascular fluid volume.

questions.text: Calculate the Amount of Intracellular Fluid in a 50 kg Woman?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 20 litre

 

Explanation:

 

The Total Body Water (TBW) in a normal adult female is approximately 50% to 60% of her body weight. This water is distributed between two main compartments: the Intra-Cellular Fluid (ICF) compartment and the Extra-Cellular Fluid (ECF) compartment. The ICF compartment typically constitutes about two-thirds of the TBW, while the ECF makes up the remaining one-third.

 

For a 50 kg woman, if we consider the TBW to be about 50% of her body weight (which is a conservative estimate for an adult female), her TBW would be:

 

TBW=50%×50kg=25litres

 

Now, to find the ICF:

 

ICF = 2/3 x TBW

ICF = 2/3 x 25 litres

ICF is about 16.67 litres

 

However, if we use the 40% value which is typically used for the ICF as a percentage of total body weight, we get:

 

ICF = 40 % × 50 kg

ICF = 0.4 × 50 kg

ICF = 20 litres

 

So, according to the 40% estimate, the intracellular fluid volume for a 50 kg woman would be 20 litres, which matches the provided answer of 20 litres.

 

Educational Objective 

 

Ref: Marino ICU book 4th edition

questions.text: A 49 years old man anorexia, malaise, nausea, dysphagia and postprandial pain is posted for subtotal gastrectomy for Ca stomach. Calculate the intra-operative replacement fluid rate in this patient if his weight is 70 kilograms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 560 ml/ hour

 

Explanation:

 

Intraoperatively Fluid is given to replace:

 

  • Deficit (due to starvation)
  • Maintenance (for insensible losses like evaporation, urine output etc.)
  • Replacement (for blood loss)

 

Replacement fluid formula

 

  • For minor surgery = 2 ml / kg body weight / hr
  • For moderate surgery = 4-6 ml/ kg body weight /hr
  • If major surgery = 8-10 ml / kg body weight / hr

 

For this patient – Gastrectomy is a major surgery, so maintenance fluid to be given is approximately 8-10 ml/kg body weight/hr = 560 ml/hr

 

Educational Objective 

 

Replacement fluid formula

For minor surgery = 2 ml / kg body weight / hr

For moderate surgery = 4-6 ml/ kg body weight /hr

If major surgery = 8-10 ml / kg body weight / hr

 

Ref: Marino ICU book 4th edition

choices.text: It can cause Renal Dysfunction.
There is risk of Anaphylactic Reaction.
All of the above are true

questions.text: What is true regarding the fluid given in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above are true.

 

Option D: Given that each of the individual options (A, B, and C) is true, option D is the correct answer. Hydroxyethyl starch is a colloid that carries risks such as renal dysfunction, is more expensive compared to crystalloids, and can cause anaphylactic reactions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This is true. The use of hydroxyethyl starch solutions (HES) has been associated with an increased risk of renal dysfunction, particularly in certain patient populations, such as those with sepsis or critically ill patients. HES can accumulate in the renal tubules, potentially leading to osmotic nephrosis-like lesions and acute kidney injury.

 

Option B. This is true. Colloids, including hydroxyethyl starch solutions, are generally more expensive than crystalloids. This cost difference can be significant, especially in settings where large volumes of fluid are required, making the choice of fluid an important economic consideration in resource-limited environments.

 

Option C. This is true. Colloids can cause hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis. Although such reactions are rare, they can be severe and potentially life-threatening, necessitating close monitoring when these solutions are administered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydroxyethyl starch, a synthetic colloid, is associated with potential renal dysfunction, higher costs, and a risk of anaphylactic reactions, which must be carefully considered when choosing fluids for resuscitation and volume expansion in clinical practice.

 

 

Ref: Marino ICU book 4th edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is posted for total colectomy under combined spinal -epidural anaesthesia. Intra-operatively and post-operatively he is given pain relief with fentanyl added in the epidural top up dose. What is the most common adverse effect of fentanyl expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Itching

 

Option A: This is true. Itching, or pruritus, is a common side effect of neuraxial opioids, including fentanyl. It is mediated by central nervous system mechanisms rather than a histamine release, as it is not typically accompanied by hives or other signs of an allergic reaction.

 

The most common side effect of fentanyl when it is used in the epidural space is indeed itching, particularly in the nose area.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. While sedation is a known side effect of opioids, including fentanyl, it is less commonly observed with epidural administration compared to systemic administration because lower doses are typically used and the drug is delivered directly to the site of action in the spinal cord.

 

Option C. Constipation is a well-known side effect of opioid medications due to their effects on the gastrointestinal system. However, when opioids are used epidurally, this effect is less pronounced than with systemic use.

 

Option D. Hypotension can occur with epidural or spinal analgesia due to blockade of sympathetic nerves, but this is more commonly associated with local anesthetics than with opioids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When fentanyl is administered epidurally, the most common side effect is itching, especially around the nose, which is a typical adverse effect of neuraxial opioids.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anaesthesia 9th Edition Pg 1426, 1434

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is posted for total colectomy under combined spinal -epidural anaesthesia. Intra-operatively and post-operatively he is given pain relief with fentanyl added in the epidural top up dose. Which of these adverse effects will you NOT expect in these patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Shortening of Motor Blockade

 

Option D: The addition of fentanyl to the epidural local anesthetic does not shorten the duration of motor blockade. While it may not prolong motor blockade, there is no mechanism by which it would reduce the duration of motor blockade produced by local anesthetics.

 

Neuraxial opioids enhance analgesic effects and can prolong the duration of the sensory blockade without significantly affecting the duration of the motor blockade.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nausea is a common side effect associated with opioid use, including fentanyl, regardless of the route of administration.

 

Option B. Vomiting similar to nausea, vomiting is also a common side effect of opioids. Fentanyl used epidurally can still enter the systemic circulation in small amounts and stimulate the chemoreceptor trigger zone, leading to vomiting.

 

Option C. Neuraxial opioids like fentanyl are known to enhance and prolong the sensory blockade when combined with local anesthetics in epidural analgesia. This is due to the synergistic effect of opioids and local anesthetics on pain pathways in the spinal cord.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When fentanyl is used as an adjunct in epidural anesthesia, it enhances sensory blockade without shortening the duration of motor blockade, while the potential for systemic side effects like nausea and vomiting still exists.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anaesthesia 9th edition pg 1426, 1434

questions.text: A patient with end stage pancreatic cancer is receiving the following drug for pain relief and palliative care.  (Insert pic of morphine tablet) since 3 months. Which of these symptoms is he not likely to develop tolerance to with to regular use of opioids?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Constipation

 

Option A: Patients often do not develop tolerance to the constipating effects of opioids. The drugs continue to slow gastrointestinal motility by binding to opioid receptors in the gut, which reduces peristalsis over long-term use. Therefore, constipation remains a persistent side effect.

 

In patients with long-term opioid therapy, such as those with end-stage pancreatic cancer, tolerance develops to many of the side effects of opioids, but not typically to constipation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Tolerance to the nausea caused by opioids often develops over time. Initially, opioids may stimulate the chemoreceptor trigger zone in the brain, causing nausea, but with continued use, the body can adapt, reducing this side effect.

 

Option C. Abdominal cramps can be a result of opioid-induced contraction of the sphincter of Oddi. Patients may develop some tolerance to this effect, but it can still occur intermittently.

 

Option D. Since tolerance to constipation typically does not develop, option D is not correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients on long-term opioid therapy are likely to develop tolerance to many side effects of opioids, such as nausea and potentially abdominal cramps, but they rarely develop tolerance to the constipating effects of the medication.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Pg 358

questions.text: While inducing a case of ASD repair, you give, Midazolam 1 mg, fentanyl at 10 micrograms/kg dose, Propofol at 2 mg/kg dose. There is difficulty in ventilation of this patient which is resolved by giving atracurium 0.5mg/kg. What could be the cause of the difficult ventilation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High Dose Fentanyl

 

Option B: This is the correct answer. High doses of fentanyl, especially when administered rapidly, can cause chest wall and glottic muscle rigidity, leading to difficulty in ventilating the patient. This phenomenon is due to the central inhibition of the release of neurotransmitters like GABA and dopamine, leading to increased skeletal muscle tone.

 

Difficulty in ventilation after induction of anesthesia with agents such as Midazolam, Fentanyl, and Propofol can be caused by several factors.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While both midazolam and fentanyl can depress respiration, they are not typically associated with acute muscle rigidity and difficulty ventilating a patient.

 

Option C. The combination of propofol and fentanyl can cause respiratory depression, but it is not commonly associated with the acute onset of muscle rigidity.

 

Option D. Inadequate depth of anesthesia can cause a patient to be responsive to pain and could theoretically lead to a situation where ventilation is difficult due to patient movement or breath-holding. However, in this case, the doses of midazolam, fentanyl, and propofol should provide adequate anesthesia depth for induction, making this less likely.

 

The treatment for opioid-induced muscle rigidity is the administration of a neuromuscular blocking agent, as was done with atracurium in this case, which resolved the issue. Another potential treatment, as mentioned, is naloxone, an opioid antagonist, but it would reverse the effects of fentanyl entirely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High doses of fentanyl can cause chest muscle rigidity, leading to difficulty in ventilation, which can be resolved with neuromuscular blocking agents or naloxone.

 

Ref: Stoelting's Pharmacology and Physiology in Anesthetic Practice, 5th Edition, Page-237-239.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney failure has received morphine PCA for post-operative pain relief. In the ward he is found to have a SpO2 of 86% on room air and respiratory rate of 5/minute. What would be the causative compound for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Morphine-6-Glucouronide

 

Option C: Morphine is metabolized in the liver to several products, including Morphine-3-Glucuronide (M3G) and Morphine-6-Glucuronide (M6G). M6G is a more potent opioid agonist than morphine itself and can lead to significant respiratory depression, especially in the setting of renal failure where its excretion is impaired.

 

In patients with chronic kidney failure, the use of morphine can lead to the accumulation of its metabolites due to decreased renal clearance. The condition described, with a low SpO2 and decreased respiratory rate, suggests opioid-induced respiratory depression.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. (Morphine-1-Glucuronide) and Option D (Morphine-8-Glucuronide) are not recognized metabolites of morphine.

 

Option B (Morphine-3-Glucuronide) is a metabolite but is not known to cause significant respiratory depression; it may actually have neuroexcitatory effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that in patients with renal impairment, morphine-6-glucuronide can accumulate and is responsible for opioid-induced respiratory depression, due to its potency as an opioid agonist and decreased clearance.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Pg 354

questions.text: A patient has to be given an ultrasound guided supraclavicular brachial plexus block for surgery of distal end of radius. Calculate the maximum dose of lignocaine with adrenaline that can be given if his weight is 60 kg.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 420 mg

 

Explanation:

 

In the injectable form, maximum dose of lignocaine which can be given alone is 5mg/kg.

When combined with epinephrine 1: 200,000, maximum dose which can be used is 7mg/kg.

 

Maximum dose of topical lidocaine is 4.5mg/kg up to 300mg.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anaesthesiology 7th edition, page 492

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with ischemic heart disease is posted for Coronary artery bypass graft surgery. You want beat to beat blood pressure measurement intraoperatively to guide you through the hemodynamic changes. Which among the following is the ideal artery for invasive blood pressure measurement?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radial

 

Option B: The radial artery is commonly used for arterial cannulation due to its superficial location, ease of access, and the presence of collateral circulation via the ulnar artery (which can be assessed by performing the Allen's test). The risks of complications like hematoma, infection, or ischemia are comparatively low, and it is also comfortable for the patient.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Ulnar Artery is not typically used for invasive blood pressure monitoring due to its deeper location and less favourable collateral circulation compared to the radial artery.

 

Option C. The Brachial Artery is less commonly used for continuous blood pressure monitoring because of the higher risk of complications, including arterial occlusion and nerve injury.

 

Option D. The Femoral Artery is used for invasive monitoring, especially in critical care settings or when radial access is not available. However, it carries a higher risk of infection and is not as easily accessible as the radial artery during surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Radial Artery is the preferred site for invasive arterial blood pressure monitoring in most surgical settings, including CABG surgery, because of its accessibility, the presence of collateral flow, and a lower risk of complications.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th edition, page 155

choices.text: High Amount of Unionized Fraction
High Amount of Ionized Fraction

questions.text: A 36-week primigravida with high blood pressure and seizures is posted for emergency Lower segment caesarean section. Anaesthesia of choice for the procedure is GA with Thiopentone. Thiopentone has a rapid onset of action because of?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High Amount of Unionized Fraction

 

Option B: Thiopentone has a high proportion of the drug in the non-ionized form at physiological pH, which is lipid soluble. This allows it to cross the blood-brain barrier quickly and exert its anesthetic effect.

 

Thiopentone (also known as thiopental) is a barbiturate that is often used for the induction of anesthesia due to its rapid onset of action.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While rapid redistribution is responsible for the short duration of action of thiopentone, it is not the reason for its rapid onset.

 

Option C. The ionized form of a drug is less lipid-soluble and does not readily cross the blood-brain barrier, so this would not contribute to a rapid onset of action.

 

Option D. Thiopentone is actually highly lipid-soluble, which contributes to its rapid onset of action; A low lipid solubility would hinder the drug’s ability to enter the brain and work quickly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The rapid onset of action of thiopentone is due to its high lipid solubility and the significant proportion of the drug in the non-ionized form at physiological pH, which allows for quick penetration of the blood-brain barrier. Rapid redistribution is related to the short duration of action, not the onset.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition, Page 299

questions.text: Which of these drugs are useful in Opioid related Constipation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D: All of the above

 

Since Methylnaltrexone, Alvimopan, and Naloxegol are all used for opioid-induced constipation, option D is correct.

 

All the options listed are drugs used to treat opioid-induced constipation by acting as peripheral opioid antagonists. These medications work by blocking the effects of opioids on the gut without affecting analgesia since they do not cross the blood-brain barrier or do so minimally.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Methylnaltrexone is a peripheral opioid antagonist specifically designed to treat opioid-induced constipation without crossing the blood-brain barrier, thus not interfering with the central analgesic effects of opioids.

 

Option B. Alvimopan is another peripheral opioid antagonist. It's used to prevent postoperative ileus, which is a temporary cessation of bowel motility after bowel surgery, and to treat opioid-induced constipation in patients with chronic pain.

 

Option C. Naloxegol is an oral peripherally-acting mu-opioid receptor antagonist used specifically for the treatment of opioid-induced constipation in adults with chronic non-cancer pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methylnaltrexone, Alvimopan, and Naloxegol are all peripheral opioid antagonists used to treat opioid-induced constipation, promoting gastrointestinal motility without reversing central analgesia provided by opioids.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Pg 358

questions.text: A known case of hypertension, which is well controlled on tablet Telmisartan for the past 7 years, is posted for elective laparoscopic appendicectomy. He is placed under which American Society of Anaesthesiologists (ASA) Grading?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ASA 2

 

Explanation:

 

A well-controlled hypertensive patient taking regular medication falls under ASA 2 Category.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition, Page 546

choices.text: Opioids reduce cerebral oxygen consumption, cerebral blood flow, cerebral blood volume, and intracranial pressure
Opioids usually have almost no effects on the electroencephalogram (EEG)
Opioid-induced nausea and vomiting is caused due to activation of oesophageal and gastric mucosa resulting in changes in pH and peristalsis.

questions.text: Which of these is not true regarding the Cerebral Action of Opioids?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Opioid-induced nausea and vomiting is caused due to activation of oesophageal and gastric mucosa resulting in changes in pH and peristalsis.

 

Option D: This is not true at all. Opioid-induced nausea and vomiting are primarily due to stimulation of the CTZ in the medulla, not due to direct effects on the esophageal or gastric mucosa.

 

Explanation:

 

 

Option A. This is true. Opioids are known to have a depressive effect on cerebral metabolism, which can lead to a reduction in cerebral oxygen consumption, cerebral blood flow, and intracranial pressure.

 

Option B. This is not entirely true. Opioids can cause dose-dependent changes in the EEG, including slowing of the waveforms, which is indicative of a sedative state.

 

Option C. This is true. Normeperidine, which is a metabolite of meperidine (Demerol), has been associated with central nervous system excitability and can induce seizures, particularly with high doses or in renal failure where it can accumulate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Opioid-induced nausea and vomiting are principally caused by the stimulation of the medullary chemoreceptor trigger zone, not by direct activation of the esophageal or gastric mucosa. Opioids can affect cerebral functions, reducing cerebral metabolism and potentially altering EEG patterns, and that normeperidine, a metabolite of meperidine, can cause seizures.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Pg 357-358.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient with terminal Ca breast is referred to the pain clinic for palliative care. She is started on tablet morphine which is prescribed every 15 days. She is regular in her follow up for 6 months followed by which she stops coming to the Pain OPD due to fracture neck of femur. Which of these symptoms can she experience if she stops taking the morphine tablets abruptly?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abdominal Cramps, Vomiting, Insomnia

 

Option D: Abdominal Cramps, Vomiting, Insomnia are classic symptoms of opioid withdrawal. The cessation of opioids after long-term use can lead to a hyperactive gastrointestinal tract, causing abdominal cramps and vomiting, as well as CNS stimulation, resulting in insomnia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Constipation is a common side effect of opioid use, but it is not a symptom of opioid withdrawal. Hypothermia and coma are not typical withdrawal symptoms either; they are more likely associated with opioid overdose.

 

Option B. Nausea and vomiting can indeed occur during opioid withdrawal; however, hypothermia is not a withdrawal symptom.

 

Option C. While vomiting and restlessness are symptoms of opioid withdrawal, constipation is not. In fact, patients often experience diarrhea rather than constipation when withdrawing from opioids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abrupt cessation of morphine in a patient with physical dependence will likely lead to opioid withdrawal symptoms, which include abdominal cramps, vomiting, and insomnia, reflecting autonomic hyperactivity and gastrointestinal disturbances.

 

Ref: Stoelting's physiology and pharmacology in anaesthetic practice, 5th edition, pg. 225

questions.text: A patient is posted for fracture femur fixation under general anaesthesia. You want to give opioids for pain relief. He is taking MAO inhibitors for depression since 10 years. Which of these opioids will you avoid in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meperidine

 

Option B: Meperidine (also known as pethidine) should be avoided in patients taking MAO inhibitors due to the risk of serotonin syndrome, which is a potentially life-threatening condition. Meperidine has serotonergic properties and can lead to excessive serotonin activity when combined with MAO inhibitors.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Morphine does not have significant interactions with MAO inhibitors and is generally considered safe for use in patients on these medications, although it should still be used with caution.

 

Option C. Sufentanil is a potent opioid but does not have the serotonergic activity associated with meperidine. It is typically safe for use in patients on MAO inhibitors, with careful monitoring.

 

Option D. Alfentanil is another opioid analgesic without significant serotonergic activity. It can be used in patients taking MAO inhibitors, but like all opioids, should be used judiciously and monitored closely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When treating patients on MAO inhibitors with opioids, it is crucial to avoid meperidine due to the risk of serotonin syndrome, a result of its serotonergic activity. Instead, other opioids that do not have this interaction should be considered.

 

Ref: Stoelting's physiology and pharmacology in anesthetic practice, 5th edition, pg. 230-237

questions.text: Which of the following opioid blocks sodium channels?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meperidine

 

Option B: Meperidine, also known as pethidine, has structural features that allow it to block sodium channels when administered intrathecally. This property can contribute to its analgesic effects beyond its action at opioid receptors.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tramadol does not have significant sodium channel blocking properties. It primarily works as a mu-opioid receptor agonist and inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine.

 

Option C. Fentanyl is a potent mu-opioid receptor agonist and does not have sodium channel blocking properties.

 

Option D. Morphine is the prototypical mu-opioid receptor agonist and does not block sodium channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meperidine is the opioid with sodium channel blocking properties when administered intrathecally, which contributes to its analgesic effects and can be used for labor analgesia and treatment of postoperative shivering, while being cautious of its metabolite, normeperidine, which can induce seizures.

 

Ref: Stoelting's Physiology and Pharmacology in Anesthetic Practice, 5th Edition, Pg. 229.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is posted for kyphoscoliosis repair under neuromonitoring. Anaesthesia is given using propofol and remifentanil infusion. What is the half-life of Remifentanil?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 minutes

 

Explanation:

 

The half-life of remifentanil is approximately 3 minutes. Remifentanil is unique among opioids due to its rapid onset and offset of action. This is because remifentanil is metabolized by esterases in the blood and tissues, which allows for a quick breakdown of the drug, making its pharmacokinetics largely independent of the duration of the infusion. Thus, even with prolonged infusions, the wake-up time or recovery from its effects remains rapid once the infusion is stopped.

 

This short half-life makes remifentanil an excellent choice for procedures requiring precise control of anesthetic depth and rapid recovery, such as surgeries under neuromonitoring where quick wake-up times are crucial.

 

In the context of opioid receptors, remifentanil is a selective mu-opioid receptor agonist and does not significantly act on kappa receptors. This specificity contributes to its analgesic efficacy and side effect profile, which is characteristic of mu receptor activation, including respiratory depression, analgesia, euphoria, and potential for dependence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remifentanil has a short half-life of approximately 3 minutes, is metabolized by nonspecific esterases in red blood cells and tissues, and is a selective mu-opioid receptor agonist, not acting significantly on kappa receptors, allowing for rapid recovery after discontinuation.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Pg 353-354

choices.text: Metabolized by RBC Esterase and Tissue Esterase
It shows Rapid Recovery after Discontinuation

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient is posted for intra-spinal tumour resection with evoked potential monitoring. Total intravenous anaesthesia with Propofol and remifentanil infusion was used. Which of these is not true regarding remifentanil?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acts on ‘Mu’ and ‘Kappa’ Receptor

 

Option B: Remifentanil is a potent, ultra-short-acting synthetic opioid analgesic drug. It is a selective mu-opioid receptor agonist and does not act on kappa receptors. Its selectivity for mu receptors contributes to its analgesic effects and side effect profile.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This is correct. Remifentanil is rapidly hydrolyzed by esterases found in red blood cells and tissues, leading to its quick metabolism and short half-life.

 

Option C. This is true. Remifentanil has a short half-life of about 3 minutes due to its rapid metabolism by nonspecific esterases, which makes it suitable for procedures requiring rapid onset and offset of analgesia.

 

Option D. This is also true. The rapid metabolism of remifentanil to inactive metabolites results in a quick recovery after the infusion is discontinued, minimizing the residual effects once the drug is stopped.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remifentanil is a selective mu-opioid receptor agonist with a short half-life of approximately 3 minutes due to rapid metabolism by esterases in red blood cells and tissues, leading to a quick recovery upon discontinuation. This pharmacological profile makes remifentanil ideal for use in procedures requiring tight control of anesthesia and analgesia, such as intra-spinal tumor resection with evoked potential monitoring.

 

Ref: Stoelting's Pharmacology and Physiology in Anesthetic Practice, 5th Edition, Page-237-239.

choices.text: Depends on the type of opioid.

questions.text: What happens to the “Apnoeic Threshold” when opioids are administered to a patient in sedative doses?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increases

 

Option A: This is correct. The apnoeic threshold refers to the level of carbon dioxide in the blood (PaCO2) at which a person is stimulated to breathe. When opioids are administered, they depress the respiratory centers in the brain, raising the apnoeic threshold. This means a patient can tolerate higher levels of PaCO2 before the body triggers the need to breathe. This can be dangerous as it may lead to hypercarbia and hypoxia without the natural protective mechanism of respiratory drive kicking in.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. This is not correct. Opioids do not lower the apnoeic threshold; they raise it by depressing the respiratory drive, leading to a higher tolerance for carbon dioxide.

 

Option C. This is incorrect. The apnoeic threshold does not remain the same when opioids are administered. It increases, reflecting the depressed sensitivity of the respiratory centers to carbon dioxide.

 

Option D. While different opioids have varying potencies and durations of action, they generally all increase the apnoeic threshold due to their central depressant effects on respiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that the administration of opioids in sedative doses increases the apnoeic threshold, leading to a decreased sensitivity to carbon dioxide, which may result in a higher risk of respiratory arrest due to unintended opioid overdose.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Pg 356

questions.text: A 100 kg 45-year adult female is posted for bariatric surgery under general anaesthesia. Total blood loss of 200 ml was measured during the intraoperative period. Colloid required for replacement of this blood loss would be?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 200 ml

 

Explanation:

 

For every 1 ml of blood lost, replacement with colloid is of 1ml.

 

For colloid replacement ratio is 1:1

 

For every 1 ml of blood lost, replacement with crystalloid is of 3ml.

 

Thus, for crystalloid replacement ratio is 3:1

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Marino ICU book 4th edition

questions.text: Calculate the Total body water in a 70 kg, 40 year old male patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 42 litres

 

Explanation:

 

Water forms 60% of the total body weight

 

Total body water = 0.6 x total body weight

                        = 0.6 x 70 kg

                        = 42 litres

 

Educational Objective

 

 

Ref: Marino ICU book 4th edition

questions.text: What is the most common cause of Maternal Mortality following General Anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary Aspiration

 

Option C: Pulmonary aspiration during anesthesia is particularly dangerous in pregnant women due to physiological changes during pregnancy that increase the risk of aspiration, such as decreased gastrointestinal motility and increased intra-abdominal pressure. Failed endotracheal intubation can also contribute to this risk. Mendelson's syndrome, a type of chemical pneumonitis caused by aspiration of stomach contents, is a serious complication associated with general anesthesia in obstetric patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While hypotension is a concern during anesthesia, especially due to aortocaval compression by the uterus in pregnant patients, it is not the most common cause of maternal mortality following general anesthesia.

 

Option B. Bleeding is a risk during and after childbirth; however, it is not the leading cause of death specifically related to general anesthesia.

 

Option D. Amniotic fluid embolism is a rare but serious condition that can occur during childbirth. It is not the most common cause related to general anesthesia, but it is a significant cause of maternal mortality during the peripartum period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary aspiration is the most common cause of maternal mortality associated with general anesthesia in the peripartum period, and that meticulous airway management is crucial to prevent this potentially fatal complication.

 

Ref: https://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(16)30003-1/fulltext

questions.text: The consultant anaesthesiologist in a top hospital is training his resident to use air and oxygen mixture as carrier gases for surgery stating he wants to avoid diffusion hypoxia in his patients. Diffusion hypoxia is observed in anaesthesia during?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recovery from Nitrous Oxide

 

Option D: This is the correct answer. When a patient is recovering from nitrous oxide anesthesia, the rapid efflux of N2O from the blood into the lungs can displace oxygen in the alveoli, potentially leading to hypoxemia if supplemental oxygen is not provided.

 

Diffusion hypoxia is a phenomenon that can occur during the recovery phase from anesthesia that utilizes Nitrous Oxide (N2O). Upon discontinuation of N2O, the gas rapidly diffuses out of the blood into the alveoli, which can dilute the concentration of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the alveoli. This can lead to a transient decrease in available oxygen and an impairment of the respiratory drive due to lower carbon dioxide levels. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Halothane is an anesthetic agent that does not cause diffusion hypoxia; this phenomenon is specific to the use of nitrous oxide.

 

Option B. While nitrous oxide is used during induction, diffusion hypoxia does not typically occur during induction because the patient is still receiving high concentrations of inspired oxygen.

 

Option C. Isoflurane is a volatile anesthetic that, like halothane, does not cause diffusion hypoxia. Diffusion hypoxia is primarily associated with the cessation of nitrous oxide.

 

Educational objective:

 

Diffusion hypoxia occurs during the recovery phase from nitrous oxide anesthesia and to prevent it by providing supplemental oxygen during this period. Also known as Fink effect. Management of Diffusion Hypoxia is O2 supplementation

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition, Page 296

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for Naso-Tracheal Intubation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fracture Base of Skull

 

Option D: This is the correct answer. Nasotracheal intubation is contraindicated in cases of a suspected fracture of the base of the skull due to the risk of the tube passing through the fracture site into the brain or other cranial structures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Awake nasotracheal intubation can be indicated in cases where difficult airways are expected, but the patient's protective airway reflexes are intact.

 

Option B. Nasotracheal intubation can be used when access to the oral cavity is obstructed by a tumor, allowing for surgical access and airway management simultaneously.

 

Option C. Nasotracheal intubation is often used in cases of mandibular fractures as it allows the oral cavity to remain clear for surgical repair and maintains airway patency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasotracheal intubation is contraindicated in patients with a base of skull fracture due to the risk of the tube being misplaced intracranially, while it can be a useful technique in managing the airway in cases of oral cavity obstruction or mandibular fractures.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition, Page 613

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is very apprehensive of pain due to skin prick while inserting IV line. You ask the mother to apply a cream on the IV-line site 45 minutes prior to the procedure. What are the components of this cream?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2.5% Lidocaine and 2.5% Prilocaine

 

Explanation:

 

Eutectic Mixture of Local Anaesthetic (EMLA) cream consists of a 1:1 mixture of 2.5% Lidocaine and 2.5% Prilocaine. It is used for topical anaesthesia in children and adults.

 

It is used for Painless IV cannulation, especially in children.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition, Page 492

questions.text: A child was taken for a short procedure of colonoscopy. Post-surgery he is conscious but having the mother is worried because she notices nystagmus in the child’s eyes. This can be explained with the use of which anaesthetic agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ketamine

 

Option A: Ketamine, an NMDA receptor antagonist, can cause nystagmus as part of its dissociative anesthesia effects, where the patient may appear conscious with eyes open and may have intact reflexes but is not responsive to sensory input.

 

Ketamine can cause various neurological phenomena including nystagmus due to its unique mechanism of action, which includes blocking the NMDA receptors and causing a functional dissociation between the thalamus and the limbic cortex.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Propofol typically does not cause nystagmus. It is a sedative-hypnotic agent used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia, known for its rapid onset and short duration of action.

 

Option C. Methohexital, a barbiturate, is used for induction of anesthesia and does not commonly cause nystagmus as a side effect.

 

Option D. Thiopentone, another barbiturate, is also not commonly associated with nystagmus following anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ketamine, used as a dissociative anesthetic agent, can cause nystagmus due to its antagonistic action on NMDA receptors, leading to altered sensory perception and ocular movements.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition, Page 328

choices.text: It is used to Assess Oral Cavity before Intubation.
In Class III, Tonsillar Pillars cannot be Visualized.
Higher Scores are associated with more difficulty in Intubation.
In Class III, only Hard Palate is Visible.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding Mallampatti’s classification?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) In Class III, only Hard Palate is Visible.

 

Option D: This statement is false. In a Mallampati Class III classification, the hard palate and the base of the uvula and the soft palate are visible, but the tonsillar pillars and the rest of the uvula are not.

 

The Mallampati classification is a system used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation. It is assessed by asking the patient to open their mouth and protrude their tongue as much as possible. The structures visible within the oral cavity are then used to determine the class.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This statement is true. The Mallampati classification is indeed used to assess the oral cavity as part of the preoperative evaluation before intubation.

 

Option B. This statement is true. In a Mallampati Class III, the base of the uvula, the soft palate, and the hard palate are visible, but the tonsillar pillars are not.

 

Option C. This statement is true. Higher Mallampati scores are associated with a greater likelihood of difficult intubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mallampati classification is used to predict difficult tracheal intubation. In Class III, both the hard and soft palates are visible, but the tonsillar pillars and the full uvula are not. A higher Mallampati score indicates a higher likelihood of difficult intubation.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition, Page 570

choices.text: To have an Oximeter
Mark the Correct Site for Surgery
Give an Antibiotic within 60 minute of making an Incision
None of the above

questions.text: All of the following are the components of WHO’s 19-point surgical safety checklist except –
questions.solution:
Ans. D) None of the above.

 

Option D: The World Health Organization's (WHO) surgical safety checklist is designed to improve patient safety by prompting the surgical team to perform certain checks at critical points in the perioperative process. All the options listed are indeed components of the WHO's 19-point surgical safety checklist.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The use of a pulse oximeter is recommended by the WHO surgical safety checklist to monitor the patient's oxygen saturation throughout the procedure.

 

Option B. The correct surgical site must be marked to prevent wrong-site surgery, and this is a critical component of the checklist.

 

Option C. Administering prophylactic antibiotics within 60 minutes before incision to reduce the risk of surgical site infections is also a key component of the checklist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that the WHO's surgical safety checklist includes a series of checks designed to improve surgical outcomes and patient safety, including the use of a pulse oximeter, marking the correct surgical site, and administering prophylactic antibiotics within 60 minutes of incision. The checklist has been shown to significantly reduce complications and improve overall surgical care.

choices.text: Second Gas Effect

questions.text: At the end of Anesthesia after discontinuation of Nitrous Oxide, 100% Oxygen is Administered to the patient to prevent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diffusion Hypoxia

 

Option A: This is correct. When nitrous oxide is discontinued at the end of an anesthetic procedure, the gas rapidly exits the blood and enters the alveoli. This can dilute the oxygen in the alveoli, potentially leading to a drop in the arterial oxygen tension, a phenomenon known as diffusion hypoxia. To prevent this, 100% oxygen is given to replace the nitrous oxide and maintain a high level of oxygen in the alveoli.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The second gas effect is the enhanced uptake of a second inhaled gas, such as oxygen, when nitrous oxide is used concurrently because nitrous oxide is taken up more rapidly into the bloodstream. This is not what we are preventing by administering oxygen at the end of anesthesia.

 

Option C. Hyperoxia, or too much oxygen, is not typically what we aim to prevent in this context; instead, it is the potential hypoxia due to the washout of nitrous oxide.

 

Option D. Oxygen is not administered specifically to prevent bronchospasm after the discontinuation of nitrous oxide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At the end of anesthesia, administering 100% oxygen after discontinuation of nitrous oxide helps prevent diffusion hypoxia, which can occur when the nitrous oxide rapidly exits the bloodstream into the alveoli, displacing oxygen.

choices.text: Clinically by Auscultation
Airway Pressure Measurement

questions.text: An infant with respiratory distress was intubated. The fastest and accurate method to confirm intubation
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capnography

 

Option A: This is correct. Capnography measures the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the respiratory gases and provides immediate feedback on the status of ventilation. The presence of a capnographic waveform confirms that the tube is in the trachea and that CO2 is being exhaled from the lungs, indicating proper intubation.

 

The fastest and most accurate method to confirm endotracheal tube placement in an intubated infant is:

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. While auscultation is a common method to assess tube placement, it is not as definitive or immediate as capnography. There can be false positives with sounds transmitted from the stomach or upper airway.

 

Option C. A chest X-ray is a confirmatory test for intubation, but it is not fast since it requires the radiology department's involvement and time to take and interpret the X-ray.

 

Option D. Measuring airway pressures can help indicate whether the tube is in the trachea (as pressures will vary with respiration), but it is not as immediate or specific as capnography.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capnography is the fastest and most accurate method for confirming endotracheal tube placement because it provides immediate confirmation that the tube is in the trachea by detecting exhaled carbon dioxide.

questions.text: Which is the muscle relaxant that can be used in a patient with high serum bilirubin of 6.0 and serum creatinine of 4.5 mg/ dL?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atracurium

 

Option A: Atracurium is a neuromuscular blocking agent that undergoes Hofmann elimination, a process that occurs at a physiological pH and temperature independent of organ function. It is also broken down by nonspecific esterases in the plasma. Because of these unique pathways, atracurium is a suitable muscle relaxant for patients with hepatic and renal impairment.

 

In patients with significant liver and kidney dysfunction, as indicated by high serum bilirubin and creatinine levels, the choice of muscle relaxant is important to prevent accumulation and prolonged effect.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Vecuronium is primarily eliminated by hepatic metabolism and to a lesser extent by renal excretion. In patients with liver and kidney dysfunction, vecuronium could have a prolonged duration of action.

 

Option C. Pancuronium is largely dependent on renal excretion, and to some extent, hepatic metabolism for its clearance. Therefore, it is not preferred in patients with significant liver and renal impairment.

 

Option D. Mivacurium is also broken down by plasma esterases, but its duration of action is shorter than atracurium. However, atracurium is more commonly recommended in patients with hepatic and renal impairment because its pharmacokinetics are better studied in this patient population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atracurium is the muscle relaxant of choice in patients with significant liver and kidney dysfunction due to its elimination via Hofmann degradation and plasma esterases, which are processes independent of liver and kidney function.

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct
a, b, c are correct
a, b, d are correct
b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Read the statements regarding opioid analgesics carefully:

 

  1. Tolerance does not develop to miosis and constipation.
  2. Pentazocine is a full agonist a kappa and agonist-antagonist at mu receptor
  3. Tramadol is an opioid antagonist which also inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin.
  4. Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at mu-receptor and antagonist at kappa receptor.
     

Which of the following options is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a, b, d are correct

 

Option C. Tramadol's mechanism as an opioid agonist that also inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin is crucial, especially when considering the risk of serotonin syndrome with its use. Buprenorphine's partial agonist activity at the mu-receptor makes it useful for treatment of opioid addiction and pain management due to its ceiling effect on respiratory depression.

 

Explanation:

 

Statement a. This statement is correct. Tolerance to most effects of opioids, such as analgesia, euphoria, and respiratory depression, can develop with prolonged use. However, tolerance generally does not develop to the effects of miosis (pupil constriction) and constipation.

 

Statement b. This statement is correct. Pentazocine is a kappa opioid receptor agonist and has antagonistic or partial agonistic effects at the mu-opioid receptor.

 

Statement c. This statement is incorrect. Tramadol is actually a weak mu-opioid receptor agonist, not an antagonist. It does inhibit the reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin, which contributes to its analgesic effects.

 

Statement d. This statement is correct. Buprenorphine acts as a partial agonist at the mu-opioid receptor and an antagonist at the kappa-opioid receptor.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: End Tidal Capnography.

questions.text: The names Brechner and Bethune are associated with which of the following devices?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) End Tidal Capnography

 

Explanation:

 

Brechner and Bethune contributed to the development of capnography equipment, which is now a standard monitoring tool used during anesthesia to assess the patient’s ventilatory status.

choices.text: Ramifentanil, Midazolam, Propofol
Fentanyl, Midazolam, Thiopentone Sodium
Morphine, Midazolam, Propofol
Morphine, Diazepam, Ketamine

questions.text: Which of the following combinations can be used for day care surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ramifentanil, Midazolam, Propofol

 

Explanation:

 

Drug combination used for day care surgery: Ramifentanyl, Midazolam & Propofol.

 

Ensures Smooth induction, Good immediate Recovery & Rapid return to Street fitness.

 

Propofol - Now used widely as primary induction agent.

 

Advantage:

 

  1. Rapid recovery.
  2. Low incidence of post-operative nausea & vomiting

 

Educational Objective 

The combination of drugs suitable for daycare surgery, providing smooth induction, good immediate recovery, and rapid return to normal activity, is Remifentanil, Midazolam, and Propofol
